The graduate certificate program in Human Resources offered at the Centre for Business within the School of Human Resources covers various HR functions and is taught by experienced HR professionals. Upon completion of the program, students will be able to: describe employment legislation impact on HR, design HR policies and programs, facilitate employee training and development, ensure health and safety in the workplace, recruit and select employees, promote diversity, manage performance, recommend strategic change initiatives, develop a total rewards system, manage employee/labour relations, and create a comprehensive human resources plan. For students aiming to pursue the Certified Human Resources Professional designation (CHRP), all applicable courses are HRPA approved. The program is offered in a fully online format for applicants of the Human Resources Management Online Postgraduate program (B428). The degree requires completion of one semester of work experience, either co-op or internship. Graduates of this program can find employment opportunities across various sectors including financial institutions, retail, manufacturing, government, legal firms, human resources consulting firms, and not-for-profit organizations.

The Human Resources (HRM) B408 program at the college offers courses in various areas including Financial and Managerial Accounting, Project Management, Human Resource Management, Organizational Effectiveness, Recruitment and Selection, Training and Development, Compensation, Labour Relations and Collective Agreements, Employment and Human Rights Law, Human Resources Planning, Occupational Health and Safety, HR Seminar Series, People Analytics, Work Experience Prep Course, and a Work Experience term. Students who wish to gain further knowledge and practical experience in training and development may pursue an optional stream in this area and choose to pursue the Certified Training and Development Professional Designation (CTDP) offered through the Institute of Performance and Learning. In total, students must complete 14 mandatory courses and one work experience term to graduate from the program. The required courses for Semester 1 include ACCT 4005, Financial and Managerial Accounting; BUS 4017, Project Management; HRM 4003, Human Resource Management; HRM 4004, Organizational Effectiveness; HRM 4005, Recruitment and Selection; and HRM 4008, Training and Development. Semester 2 courses include HRM 4009, Compensation; HRM 4010, Labour Relations and Collective Agreements; HRM 4011, Employment and Human Rights Law; HRM 4012, Human Resources Planning; HRM 4013, Occupational Health and Safety; HRM 4015, HR Seminar Series; HRM 4031, People Analytics; HRM 4003 for HRM 4012, Human Resources Planning; and BUS 4000, Work Experience Prep Course. Students may also complete a work experience term with the code COOP 4003 / INTN 4003 / BAWT 4003. The equivalent course for course exemptions must be from a recognized university with a minimum grade of 70 per cent and HRPA approved, where applicable.

context: The Human Resources (HRM) B408 program at the college offers courses in various areas including Financial and Managerial Accounting, Project Management, Human Resource Management, Organizational Effectiveness, Recruitment and Selection, Training and Development, Compensation, Labour Relations and Collective Agreements, Employment and Human Rights Law, Human Resources Planning, Occupational Health and Safety, HR Seminar Series, People Analytics, Work Experience Prep Course, and a Work Experience term. Students who wish to gain further knowledge and practical experience in training and development may pursue an optional stream in this area and choose to pursue the Certified Training and Development Professional Designation (CTDP) offered through the Institute of Performance and Learning. In total, students must complete 14 mandatory courses and one work experience term to graduate from the program. The required courses for Semester 1 include ACCT 4005, Financial and Managerial Accounting; BUS 4017, Project Management; HRM 4003, Human Resource Management; HRM 4004, Organizational Effectiveness; HRM 4005, Recruitment and Selection; and HRM 4008, Training and Development. Semester 2 courses include HRM 4009, Compensation; HRM 4010, Labour Relations and Collective Agreements; HRM 4011, Employment and Human Rights Law; HRM 4012, Human Resources Planning; HRM 4013, Occupational Health and Safety; HRM 4015, HR Seminar Series; HRM 4031, People Analytics; HRM 4003 for HRM 4012, Human Resources Planning; and BUS 4000, Work Experience Prep Course. Students may also complete a work experience term with the code COOP 4003 / INTN 4003 / BAWT 4003. The equivalent course for course exemptions must be from a recognized university with a minimum grade of 70 per cent and HRPA approved, where applicable.

The text describes a Human Resources (HR) program offered by an Ontario college. Students can pursue an optional Training and Development Stream in this area and upon completion, may choose to obtain the Certified Training and Development Professional Designation (CTDP) through The Institute of Performance and Learning.

The HR program courses include:
1. HRM 4008 - Training & Development
2. HRM 4003 - Co-requisite: Training Design & Delivery
3. HRM 4008 - Coaching for Effective Performance Management
4. HRM 4003 (pre-requisite not mentioned)

The program learning outcomes cover various HR functions such as recruitment, selection and retention; performance management; training and development; employee relations; compensation; health and safety; information technologies; organizational development; communication; professional development; business planning; research and reporting.

The tuition fees for the first two semesters of the program starting in Fall 2022 are:
1. Domestic students: $5,153.00
2. International students: $17,816.00

*Please note that fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates.*
